messageBody:
Shane Duan wrote:

> The method summary, I would say. This is true especially when I was
> studying JDK 1.4 and try to learn the new classes.
>

Fair enough. Some of the method-level JavaDoc comments in the JDK are pretty good. Then again, it's very heavily used and not subject to a lot of
change.

In general, I find most method-level JavaDoc to be superfluous at best, and inaccurate at the worst. It's easy to forget to update them, so often
they lie. If I have to add a lot of comments to the method to express its intent, then it's probably doing more than it should or not well named.
Tests don't lie, so I'm inclined to look at any existing tests to determine how a method is really intended to behave. I typically use JavaDoc
simply to look up a method signature, which can easily be kept in synch with the code using an automated build process.

Mike
